intro: Prosopanche, commonly known as the "ghost flower," is a genus of flowering plants native to the Andes Mountains of South America. It is characterized by its unique, lantern-shaped flowers that are often pale or translucent, giving it an ethereal appearance. The plant is a member of the Orobanchaceae family, which includes parasitic species, and it typically grows in high-altitude environments. Prosopanche species are known for their delicate, often ephemeral blooms that appear briefly during the warmer months. Due to its rare and striking appearance, it is a subject of interest in botanical studies and conservation efforts.
